byline.contributor: Sam Borden and Jeré Longman contributed reporting.

abstract: Coaches of prominent teams in the Women's World Cup have had to rely on unconventional scouting practices amid expanded field that is crowded with relative unknowns; have used informal network of friends and associates, as well as television footage, to get handle on new contenders like Ivory Coast and Thailand; are pursuing scouting despite powerful odds in their favor, as evidenced by Germany's 10-0 victory over Ivory Coast.
lead_paragraph: Many teams have little information about their opposition from Africa and Asia.

headline.main: Scouting a Mystery World Cup Opponent Can Take Some Detective Work
headline.print_headline: Scouting? Some Coaches Rely on Colleagues and TV

snippet: Many teams have little information about their opposition from Africa and Asia.
